snippet: The decision to allow a gay group to march under its own banner in the New York parade ends a policy that has prompted protests, court battles and bitter debate for decades.
abstract: Organizers of New York City St Patrick's Day Parade lift ban on openly gay groups marching under their own banner; move brings to a close more than two decades of bitter protests and controversy that thrust annual celebration into national gay rights debate; decision is striking reflection of evolution of gay rights in the city and in American society, and is measure of changing attitudes in hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Bill Carter, Michael M. Grynbaum and Sharon Otterman, and research by Susan C. Beachy.

lead_paragraph: The decision to allow a gay group to march under its own banner in the New York parade ends a policy that has prompted protests, court battles and bitter debate for decades.

headline.main: Gay Groups to March in St. Patrick’s Day Parade as a Ban Falls
headline.print_headline: Gay Groups to March in St. Patrick’s Day Parade as a Ban Falls
